People still think the curving of free speech and the Corona mask are not related, stupid people. Here is a timeline of events since 2014.
2014 America patents coronovirus
2015 Bill Gates invests money in Wuhan lab to see if Corona is transmittable to humans
2018 Abortion referendum worldwide
2019 Coronovirus outbreak
2020 Vaccines made from aborted fetal cell lines
2021 Freedom of speech curved and you're to wear a mask to shut you up.
Tell me again how all these are coincidence ?

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree that she shouldn't be fired for reasons pertaining solely to her personal life. Whether someone shows up, on time, ready, willing, and able to do the job she's been hired for, that's all an employer should care about. I probably won't watch Aquaman 2, but that's because I'm boycotting Warner Bros. over the firing of an actor, over strictly non-professional reasons. And also because it'll probably suck, which isn't entirely unrelated to Heard, but has no connection to where she goes poo.

About her getting fired over weight, though...
Not all decisions in Hollywood are made by "Hollywood". I imagine that everyone on set is insured by the studio, and that the insurance for leading actors is very high. The insurance company will want to be certain that anyone they're insuring against accidents, with potentially enormous pay out, are as physically capable as the risks require. While an actor can be replaced by stunt doubles in most dangerous scenes, they'll still be in scenes with a higher than normal risk, and a movie set is a pretty chaotic and dangerous place to begin with. The thing about actuaries is that they don't give a shit about political correctness. They only care about minimizing the probability of having to pay out. If they've said "Heard needs to be in THIS physical shape, or no insurance", then Heard needs to be in this physical shape, or no movie -- unless she's replaced. If she isn't on schedule to be in that shape, the producers will, at a minimum, have to prepare for a short notice replacement, i.e. investigate which suitable actors will or may be free and willing to step in.

Also, actuators make for excellent cover. "There was nothing we could do; the nerd said 'the stochastic model predicted a non-standard probability of an unacceptable adverse effect on the predictive value of the actuarial table for 35 year old women on set, so fire fucking Heard, or else', and that was that. We never figured out what the former meant, so there was no arguing with the latter. We considered giving him an atomic wedgie, but he said he was insured against that". If journalists try to get an explanation from an actuary, their eyes will start glazing over within the first minute, and they'll be dead from boredom within five. They'll have no choice but to flee for their lives, and confirm that, indeed, actuaries aren't to be messed with.
snippet.textOriginal:

Whether someone shows up, on time, ready, willing, and able to do the job she's been hired for, that's all an employer should care about. I probably won't watch Aquaman 2, but that's because I'm boycotting Warner Bros. over the _firing_ of an actor, over strictly non-professional reasons. And also because it'll probably suck, which isn't entirely unrelated to Heard, but has no connection to where she goes poo.

About her getting fired over weight, though...
Not all decisions in Hollywood are made by "Hollywood". I imagine that everyone on set is insured by the studio, and that the insurance for leading actors is very high. The insurance company will want to be certain that anyone they're insuring against accidents, with potentially enormous pay out, are as physically capable as the risks require. While an actor can be replaced by stunt doubles in most dangerous scenes, they'll still be in scenes with a higher than normal risk, and a movie set is a pretty chaotic and dangerous place to begin with. The thing about actuaries is that they don't give a shit about political correctness. They only care about minimizing the probability of having to pay out. If they've said "Heard needs to be in THIS physical shape, or no insurance", then Heard needs to be in this physical shape, or no movie -- unless she's replaced. If she isn't on schedule to be in that shape, the producers will, at a minimum, have to prepare for a short notice replacement, i.e. investigate which suitable actors will or may be free and willing to step in.

Also, actuators make for excellent cover. "There was nothing we could do; the nerd said 'the stochastic model predicted a non-standard probability of an unacceptable adverse effect on the predictive value of the actuarial table for 35 year old women on set, so fire fucking Heard, or else', and that was that. We never figured out what the former meant, so there was no arguing with the latter. We considered giving him an atomic wedgie, but he said he was insured against that". If journalists try to get an explanation from an actuary, their eyes will start glazing over within the first minute, and they'll be dead from boredom within five. They'll have no choice but to flee for their lives, and confirm that, indeed, actuaries aren't to be messed with.
